ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Course readings
There were no other modes of learning.
It was a virtual seminar.
In addition to discussion, guest speakers were also invited to conduct virtual seminars. All learning was remote.
Breakout rooms

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how to read a philosophy paper, how to formulate a good discussion question that pulls from the main themes of the text, what masculinity's historical context is as well as how to dissect masculinity in a philosophical context.
Learned to think very differently and question lots of assumptions and structures that exist in society.

This first year seminar taught me how to approach philosophy readings differently than other readings. It developed my skills to be able to access the richness of philosophy texts, and how to respond to these texts by asking insightful questions. I also learned to challenge my own beliefs, and found a process to filter information that I learn.

This course made me look at the world in a more introspective manner that revealed how interconnected the norms and assumptions we live by are. I learned how to properly read a philosophy paper and how important looking at a researcher's sources is. I also learned how to properly voice my thoughts on sophisticated topics in a way that allowed others to understand what I wished to say.
A more systematic understanding of gender theories.
Learned how to thoughtfully analyze, challenge, and construct philosophical arguments. Primarily focused on gender theory.

I learned how to understand and analyze philosophy papers. I learned how to have an effective seminar discussion and use evidence to back up my points. I learned about the interconnected was of the patriarchy with race and class.

I learned about the metaphysics of masculinity. We talked covered things like different forms of masculinity, and how these interact with each other to sustain the patriarchy. Another big theme throughout the course was the intersectionality of gender with race, class, sexuality, etc. Also, I learned how to critically read and analyze philosophical papers about gender and masculinity.

Analytical philosophy, gender theory, what a 'social construction' is, how feminist science works, and different ways of thinking about masculinity. I also learned the difference between 'men' and 'male'.

This course shaped the way that I currently think about gender and masculinity, and equipped me with tools to approach my experience of gender in a more precise way. It also lent me insight into different experiences of gender that allow me to criticize popular representations and conceptions of gender in the movies and TV I watch as well as the books I read.
I learned how to read philosophical readings and ask philosophical questions.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course was fantastic. I would say the biggest strength was that everyone was extremely interested in the topic at hand which allowed for great discussions. I would say that the only weakness this course had was that oftentimes the reading for class would be so dense that breaking down the text (to help us understand it) would take way too much time and would leave little time to discuss the larger picture.
This course was very well organized. Each reading built on knowledge from questions explored the previous week which made the course cohesive and fulfilling.

The course had great readings, lively discussion, and interesting guest speakers. Most days I felt we ran out of time to give the readings their due justice but besides that I felt the course was exciting and well structured.
Loved every second.
More connection with the professor

Professor was greatly helpful and adept in leading, prompting, and continuing thoughtful discussion about reading materials. Course materials are somewhat consistent in format (written philosophical text), which can be taken as either a strength or a weakness of the course.
I enjoyed the seminar style of this class. It kept us engaged. I would have liked some more guidance about how to read philosophy papers and maybe define some key philosophy terms.
This class was the most engaging class that I took this semester. The material was relevant and exciting, and I always felt eager to learn more. I cannot think of any weaknesses of this course.
Strengths: Everything! The readings are fascinating, the discussions are interesting and lively, the professor (Dembroff) is totally inspirational and whip-smart.

This was an incredibly strong course. I appreciated the intimate, breakout-room-oriented format, as I believe it helped ensure that all students were engaged. I also think the unique grading approach aided in student engagement with material that would be too intimidating otherwise. I wish that there had been more writing throughout the semester.

Student engagement was super strong; the discussions we had as a class was non-stop and lasted up to 30 minutes. Students were held accountable by: 1) having a discussion question ready for every class and 2) discussing in smaller breakout rooms. 
For someone with zero background on philosophy, it was, at most times, hard to contribute to the discussion. Because there was no vocabulary review or a general run-down of the reading, it was difficult to keep up with the conversations.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Although a virtual format will always change the feel of a seminar, I thought that this course did a good job adapting to the learning environment of the COVID-19 pandemic, and it put in measures so that everyone's voice was heard (including but not limited to using the "raising hands" feature on zoom, and going into low-pressure break out rooms and then coming back together).

This class, from my perspective, had the best structure for proper Zoom learning. The expectation of having a presentation followed by breakout rooms for discussion meant that we all got to participate and voice our thoughts in an organic, safe manner and the expectation of an end, communal discussion meant that there rarely was any awkward Zoom moments. I loved this class for this very reason. It was as close as you could get to what I would expect is an in-person first-year seminar.
There was a lot of time for discussion and overall engagement (in class and in the discussion posts) was very high.
More connection with other students
Seminar and discussion board formats were incredibly engaging!
The small class setting allowed me to succeed. It kept me engaged. Additionally the topic was engaging and something I felt passionate about learning.
I think this class worked very effectively despite the circumstances provided by the pandemic because of the small seminar environment.

The majority of the course assignments were twice-weekly discussion board posts, in which each student developed and motivated a discussion question based on the assigned reading. Though I sometimes scrambled to finish my posts, I found them to be a good way to recap what I had read and formulate a cohesive response to the material. Professor Dembroff was also very chill about discussion posts turned in a few hours late, though they were sure to let us know when it was crucial that we turn in our questions on time (for instance, if we were expecting a speaker the following day). This flexible approach made this class well-suited to virtual learning.

There is little room for improvement, but I think that limiting the time students are allowed to spend on in-class presentations would help. Some students finished within 15 minutes, while other presentations filled the entire class time.

The assignmentsbi-weekly comments on the Canvas course pageheld students accountable while also allowing students to have one thing to contribute to the discussion. The professor often asked questions that would allow the discussion to continue.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely! Although I don't really enjoy philosophy itself (and doubt I will take another philosophy class) I enjoyed the topic at hand. I would highly recommend this as an introductory philosophy course as it introduces you to the realm of philosophy using both philosophical and non philosophical texts. The workload itself might be low but the course, by no means, was easy. You have to be willing to read and reread texts until you can fully understand them.

Yes. I think that it is important for every student to take a course that challenges the way they think about the world. This course made me challenge many of my beliefs, and it was an incredible opportunity to be able to discuss some of these things with other students, professors, and professionals in the philosophy field.
Yes, I already have. Professor Dembroff was great and the readings made me turn inward whilst looking outward. This class was the best choice I made this semester.
Yes. Recommended for anyone who is curious about the way gender functions in our world.
Yes
I would recommend this course to any student interested in philosophy, especially gender theory.

Yes I would. We discuss topics that are so essential and prevalent in the world we live in. It is important to be aware of how these issues occur in our lives and Professor Dembroff provides great insight into patriarchy and masculinity, allowing us to discover and see multiple perspectives to come to our own conclusions.

I would highly recommend this course to another student, even if they are not a philosophy or WGSS major. The material that is covered in this class will completely change the way you think about our society, in which gender is a potent and active force.

YES! 100%. This course was by far my favorite course that I've taken at Yale so far. If you have the opportunity to do so, take this class, or any class that's offered by Prof. Dembroff. They are an incredible professor and the material is so interesting and relevant.

I would definitely recommend this course. I think that it was a phenomenal first experience at Yale, especially as a stem student, to be able to experience philosophy as directly applicable to my daily life. It is one of those few courses that can alter perspectives, while not having any prerequisite knowledge.

I would recommend this course to first-years because, despite not having a background on philosophy, I was able to at least contribute one thing in each of our class discussions. The professor is very understanding and offers a great introduction to philosophy.
